author: bluejacket57
body:
I'm long-term bullish on Unity due to the potential of it being the next Adobe, AutoDesk, etc and the fact that the market is definitely a lot bigger for there to be a player outside of Epic Games (especially with most of Unity's revenue coming from ads/e-commerce rather than licensing like Epic)

But short-term, I expect this price to come down. It's extremely odd to say the least that Unity and Snowflake are rocketing up while the rest of tech is coming down...it points to the fact that growth/tech investors are parking their money here and will be shorted later. So I believe in unity long term, but I'm going to wait to jump in.

author: Only_As_I_Fall
body:
Just reading their S-1 I don't think it's nearly as large a market as they think.

>industries beyond gaming, we estimate the market opportunity for our Create Solutions and Operate Solutions to be approximately $17 billion today, based on the number of software developers, architects and designers our solutions could potentially serve. 

Which is $5 billion more than they estimated the value of the gaming market to be as of 2019.

Surely there's some need for interactive 3D, but the product examples they give are not compelling. Here are all the examples they give in the s-1 of non-gaming uses of their technology:

>Architecture:    For architects, transforming building development and architectural data for the 3D world has been a challenge. Seemingly small post-design changes can take months to rework. Architects, designers and project partners use this real-time 3D to simultaneously contribute to the planning and development of a building with rapid, cost-effective iteration. Onsite construction teams and technicians can visualize before, and as they build. Interactive, 3D designs can be virtually overlaid onto actual construction through augmented reality, to detect design flaws early, which significantly reduces the risk of future rebuilds and drives project efficiencies. 

First of all professional CAD tools are hellishly complex which makes the market entrenched and difficult to disrupt. Architectural tools are not where you want lots of frills and real time effects, so I'm not sure what they think they are contributing over traditional 3D cad tools in terms of planning and design stages. Existing tools are hundreds of iterations deep and have huge momentum based on their widespread use among college professors, newly graduated engineers and seasoned designers. That unity can leverage their 3d game engine to disrupt that market is laughable.

There is however the VR/AR aspect, which probably does have some merit. That said, I just don't see how much money is really worth it for an architect or designer to be able to strap on a be helmet and look at their design. Keep in mind that the target audi nice here is already comprised of people who are necessarily very good at visualizing objects and spaces from 2d schematics.

As for AR used to aid in construction, I have no doubt that it has potential to ease certain aspects of large projects. That said, setting up and maintaining accurate AR on an active build site is not a solved problem, and I'm unconvinced many builders would find the marginal benefits to be worth potentially large cost increases.

Then you have this

>Automotive:    The automotive industry is often challenged by a long, slow development cycle for new car models. The traditional process involves disparate tools in the iterative creation and recreation of a new model. Real-time 3D technology is driving efficiencies in car development and sales cycles, allowing for interactive, life-like models of cars to be rendered in real-time. These “digital twins” can be used for marketing or personalized sales experiences at dealerships and online. 

 Their whole argument here is basically that real time 3D and VR can be used as a sales gimmick. I think it could be useful for initial car shopping, but people are always going to want to physically sit in their cars (and test drive them) before the purchase. Of course more car shopping is being done online now due to covid, but unless the covid crisis continues for much longer than public health officials expect (passed 2021) I think unity may be too late to take advantage of that temporary market.

I guess the question here is how valuable would this be as a marketing tool really? Is it worth billions of dollars to allow shoppers to pretend to sit in a car? Who owns the VR equipment in this case, the dealership or the purchaser? Does this rely on much broader VR adoption than we've seen in recent years?

Then the last example they give is this:

>Film:    Filmmakers are finding that real-time technology yields faster results and provides more creative freedom than traditional filming and editing solutions. Real-time technology removes the need for server farms that generate single frames over hours, eliminating the need to wait days for dailies or for servers to fully render a digital scene. Because creation becomes be real-time, a filmmaker can edit and review a scene instantly, allowing higher quality productions to reach audiences more quickly. 

Which honestly is the most laughable part. The implication here seems to be that unity's realtime engine will allow filmmakers to preview their work without having to wait for the full render. This is obviously invaluable when iterating visual computer generated effects and animations, which is why every professional 3D suite already has this capability. Why would you export your scene to a unity 3d tool for real time rendering when Maya [can already do this](https://knowledge.autodesk.com/support/maya/learn-explore/caas/CloudHelp/cloudhelp/2020/ENU/Maya-Rendering/files/GUID-2FFD2E18-DEAC-4D73-8F07-082FAD5B4A16-htm.html)? The only way into this market for unity is either to replace Autodesk's existing real time renderer (which would be expensive and hold no benefit for Autodesk) or replace tools such as Maya and others entirely (which again would be hellishly expensive and time consuming)

TL;DR 

The market just isn't as big as unity claims it is, and the examples of non-game applications are far from convincing.

author: vicividivenito
body:
Unity is mostly used for the entertainment industry, video games and visual effects. I don't need to explain the importance in video games. But for the visual effect, maya isn't used as a real-time engine, in fact Autodesk doesn't have a robust real time rendering engine and their software is mostly used for animating or creating the 3D meshes which are then exported to another software like unity or in the API to render engines like arnold or vray (which are not real-time). Similarly for Autocad project you would do the same thing, build it once in Autocad and then the designer/architect would export it and make the futures changes in unity using AI and some scripting.

Real-time rendering is much faster than any renderer used for film and television, which produce the same quality for the most part, so it can be very useful on a film set to have the director watching his render already done as a temporary real-time version or for a pre-vis company like "the third floor" to produce the whole movie in matter of few months for the director and producers to carefully schedule and redesign the movie based on the objectives of the producing company very fast.
Weta has some existing real-time proprietary software that are already doing that I beleive. Autodesk products are complimentary of all of these tools, they are essential but they don't make it at the whole.

author: GromGrommeta
body:
No need to apologize, we all make mistakes and I also apologize if my tone came off as rude. I tend to be fact-oriented and get annoyed when I see opinions without facts behind them which is probably 90% of this sub's content these days.

Those auto-trading apps might be worthy of a post. People might benefit from your experience. 

Also, Unity is a household name for engineers, software/game developers, animators, and is becoming increasingly relevant in a number of other industries. Good comparison to Autodesk, so maybe look at the relative valuations and financials of those two companies and see which you think presents the better value. I'm seeing ADSK as the better value right now while U is pretty trendy. But that's only part of the picture.

Autodesk vs Unity would also be a good post. Would love to hear from people who have experience with both.

The qualitative information I gathered from people in the industry/who actually use Unity is very favorable. It's still a speculative position for me (<1% of portfolio). If it goes down but I still see a growth story, I'll buy more. If it goes up and solidifies as a major player in a number of industries, I'd buy more. If its revenue growth accelerates and/or its path to profitability becomes clearer, I'd buy more.

Best of luck to you

author: PDXdesign
body:
My experience with them is their deciding software in the Architecture industry. They make the competitive software suite to Autodesk Revit.

As an Architect I have major issues with Autodesk and their businesses practices. I hope for a competitor to replace them or at least keep them honest.

I don’t think Bentley is the answer unfortunately. Anecdotal I know, but I don’t know if a single firm outside of a few Midwest mom and pop shops that use their software. 

Also Autodesk has a stranglehold on public work which often times requires a Revit model (Autodesk software) as their deliverable, Autodesk is taught in all schools, people have made entire careers learning how to use Revit (myself included), and they’ve broken the market open expanding from Architecture firms to contractors as well.

It’d be a dream for Bentley to get bought but a competitor and get a huge infusion of money and effort.

author: captainhaddock
body: I suggest some profitable software-as-a-service companies. Adobe, Ansys, Autodesk. And Mastercard.

author: Thraex_Exile
body:
Thank you for the input. I’ll have to compare those 2 more. ADSK definitely has itself cemented in my field, and I’d assume that means it’s still pretty solid everywhere else where it’s possible. I’d be open to Unity taking ahold though. Even if it’s not better, Autodesk just releases a better version of their existing software every couple decades and then rakes in the cash off annual ineffective updates on multiple similar programs, they’ve basically made themselves their own competition and make everyone else pay for it.

I’d be worried we’ll see steady growth from ADSK and one day it’d just free fall once people realize there ar either options. Once the engineers commit to it, everyone else will follow suit fast. I appreciate the perspective!

author: Blackops_21
body: Banks learned from 08 and have contingency plans in place and are very profitable. ConocoPhillips had 2.83b revenue this quarter and still reported positive earnings of over a quarter billion. That's during a pandemic. Most tech companies are not profitable, they consistently report negative earnings. Autodesk, an actual profitable tech company had revenue of 913m and earnings of 98m this quarter and they have a 10b market cap lead over ConocoPhillips (who made 3x as much as them during their worst quarter in years). People talk about the dotcom crash because tech market caps are massively inflated and they have much, much further to fall to get in line with their fundamentals.

author: Only_As_I_Fall
body:
How do you make accurate modifications to cad files in unity when the unity engine doesn't even have native decimal support?

Also did you forget the part where Autodesk has viewport for realtime rendering already? What does unity add to that besides a complicated and inaccurate conversion process?

author: snake250
body:
Exactly, I'd like to know as well. NOTE: the question is not which stocks have sustained *no* P/E - there's a ton of companies that don't have positive earnings but that continue to go up in price. Sometimes this is fine for a sustained period, sometimes it's not.

But which companies *do* have earnings, but consistently trade at 500+ P/E?

Amazon is the most well-known company that for years has traded at a high P/E (usually around 100), but as far as "serious" businesses with a proven track record go, Amazon is a special case because people know it's still a very strong company in cash flow terms.

Once a company starts to earn, high multiples aren't usually allowed for very long.

Nvidia and AMD are companies that have been trading at pretty high P/Es for quite some time now. Maybe 100 is the new 30 and 500 is the new 100 then? :/

P.S. If I had the balls, inclination, ability and skill to short (I don't short), I would do a diversified short basket shorting the top 5-10 highest P/E companies in this market (including TSLA). Edit: this would be a hell of a heart attack portfolio, basically (> $25B market cap, EPS of at least a penny), you'd end up short: DDOG, TSLA, ZM, SQ, AMD, ADSK. Totally don't have the balls to do it but I do believe those companies are overvalued just knowing what the current market's about rn.

author: Thraex_Exile
body:
Interesting! Thank you

I’ve had to work in autodesk applications pretty much daily but my field doesn’t take to change very often - most people are still using autocad for elevations and plans of complex structures and meshes vs revit even though it’s all autodesk for instance. I’ve mostly just heard about the gaming applications and that it could be used for simulations or other 3D activities, so cool to know there are people actively using it.

I was lucky enough to get a couple shares when it first came out, but I’m not sure it’s a business I would want to invest in for long as, like you said, it seems like it will be an uphill battle. My industry doesn’t even talk about it, at least not in my area, so I’d imagine you’re right it still has some time before becoming a real product for the mainstream market.

author: Thraex_Exile
body:
Thank you, and once again sorry was not intending to lead people to believe I was just looking for free advice and duck out. I did look into it, but investing in general is new to me. I have usually relied on auto-trading apps and have started realizing that I’m taking a lot of short-term hits since all they’re looking at is long-term benefit based on very immediate information. Ended up losing way too much these last couple week when investing on my own would have been better. So thank you for helping me understand what factors would be better to look for in the future.

Your last point is what I was looking for. End of the day, I’m still gonna be up most the weekend looking at companies to consider over the next couple months and when I should invest in them. I’ve been just trying to understand why investors were bullish on them, as Unity has been around for awhile but never seemed to break out like the other tech in this field like Autodesk or the Unreal engine, despite having plenty of chances to gain public visibility. Just seems like something’s missing for them to become a major player, and was looking for someone that would know what that was or if this was just their limit.

author: Chroko
body:
>as Unity has been around for awhile but never seemed to break out like the other tech in this field like Autodesk or the Unreal engine, despite having plenty of chances to gain public visibility. Just seems like something’s missing for them to become a major player

Unity has been at or near the top of popularity charts going back several years. It has far more market penetration than Unreal, particularly for mobile and in certain foreign markets.

>Just seems like something’s missing for them to become a major player 

I'm curious where your perception comes from, it seems like they're already the one to beat and are well-poised to ride the expansion of the industry.

author: iyioi
body:
Solidworks maybe, for tracking things with many complicated parts. Every screw and washer is accounted for and has a part number. Catia for car and boatbuilders. 

But every road, bridge, curb, landscape plan, building, garage, house, driveway, parking structure, etc... that’s almost all Autodesk. 

And solidoworks is losing market share to Autodesk fusion 360, which is taking over the 3D design and printing world.

author: buildyr
body:
Ok. Is someone saying that VR won't work at some point in the future? 

Many industries are already starting to dip their toes into VR - especially in architecture/construction. There's also billions of dollars currently being poured into the industry from companies like Microsoft, Facebook, Google, Tencent, Sea Ltd, Sony and others. That doesn't even include the software side of things with companies like Unity, Epic, MatterPort, Autodesk and others continuing to invest in the VR/AR side. 

I'd imagine that it will become more common across a variety of industries especially when you're projecting out over the next decade. It will also become more accessible as hardware and technology get cheaper to manufacture.

author: Chroko
body:
My background is games, so be aware that's the perspective I'm writing this from.

I'll admit I don't have a handle on the architecture side of the industry, but I don't understand how Autodesk is a competitor to Unity. Autodesk discontinued their Stingray game engine in 2017 and now offer tools that [work with Unity](https://www.autodesk.com/solutions/real-time-rendering) for doing real-time visualizations.

Yes, some Autodesk tools (Maya, 3DS Max, MudBox) are used by artists to make game assets that are then dropped into another game engine such as Unreal or Unity. But they're specialized, only used by a few members of a game team and have competition from other tools (Blender, ZBrush and Adobe's Substance Designer for example.)

Note that a lot of these tools and engines are very "sticky", in that game developers and companies take time to get comfortable and then stay with them for years. They are also the product of their generation: Unreal is still more popular for PC games because it was first; Unity is more popular for making mobile games because it addressed those platforms first.

For example: Amazon even has their own game engine (Lumberyard) but basically nobody uses it - even though it's effectively free - because Unity or Unreal are more mature and the preferred tools for most developers.

Anyway, here are Unity's own numbers:

[https://unity.com/our-company](https://unity.com/our-company)

>*2019 - 51% of games were powered by Unity (PC/console/top mobile games combined)*

And on some more:

[https://techcrunch.com/2020/09/10/how-unity-built-a-gaming-engine-for-the-future/](https://techcrunch.com/2020/09/10/how-unity-built-a-gaming-engine-for-the-future/)

>*Unity dominates in mobile games — now the largest (and fastest growing) segment of the gaming industry — where it has over 50% market share and where Unreal is not a common alternative. Unity has kept the largest market share in AR and VR content, at over 60%.*

author: curiouscat887
body:
Basically my strategy is to look at the earning calls for the week, on the day the companies earnings are announced I usually search for that ticker and see if there are any alerts.

Something with high volume and low IO that’s quite far out with a short expiry looks like a bet to me so I look into the company a bit more and then follow the bet. 

I know it’s not rock solid but these are gambles after all.

Most have made something like 20-30% within a few hours later. 

I missed the CRM one even tho I was going to do it, kicking myself for that, but with the ZM one I thought why not as it was 1.35 a contract.

Just wish I put 10k into it as I’d have 400k now and could retire on theta haha but hindsight is 20/20

author: nebuloushazybull
body:
For all you asking: “Wait, how tf did [insert CRWD, RKT, CLDR, etc] tank & ZM 🚀 to fucking 40%?”

And being like: “Fuck this market, this is rigged, it can’t be like that, etc.” 

Quit your bitching and process one thing and process it well. Read it 10-1000 times if you have to.

We’re in a fucking pandemic. Only the top dogs/upcoming and unfortunately overvalued as fuck monsters like ZM & CRM are gonna dominate and destroy agenda-related items like quarterly earnings. Their leaders and engineers don’t give a shit about how much their shares have gone up this past month or year. Even if they do; they care much more about making their products or services the only and most attractive offering in their domain.

Stop latching on to what you heard or what you think you may know of a company. If it’s not the top of its game or the leader in what it’s doing, even if new or old, assess against the current situation and play accordingly.

Yes ZM & CRM may not deserve the followed surges but hey, is anyone gonna need any less of either of these 2, especially during these times? Prolly not.

Cheers.

author: SnooRobots6193
body:
Just looking at some of the biggest top performers this year:

* AMZN PE Sept 2016: 192 (now 127)
* FB PE Sept 2016: 57 (now 34)
* CRM PE Sept 2016: 240 (now 99)
* NFLX PE Sept 2016: 310 (now 87)
* ABMD PE Sept 2016: 130 (now 80)
* DPZ PE Sept 2016: 41 (now 34; not a tech giant, but I bring it up cause it's among the most overlooked top performer of 2010s IMO).

And I didn't choose to compare with 2016 because it was some peak. The market climbed pretty much the entirety of 2017.

Obviously this list was handpicked and there are plenty of counterexamples, but the point is that growth companies have had growth priced in (and delivered on it) for many years.

author: infinitelimits00
body:
So this is the theoretical explanation. Basically the IV increased so much to overwhelm any loss of delta, which is quite a big move in itself. So essentially a ton of people bought a ton of upside calls today could account for this massive IV increase. 

However, from a trading perspective this seems super exploitable. Essentially here's what it's implying. 

It's saying Yesterday there was an X % chance for Tesla to be > 800 (or pick any other upside strike) by September 18. Now Today, despite Tesla going down 4-5% at this current point, there is still an X % chance or even > X% chance for Tesla to be > 800 by September 18. That's insane!

Despite 1 day passing by and a 4-5% drop in stock, the probability, according to MM, didn't change or even increased at certain points in the day! And it's not like there's that many days until September 18 anyways.

I feel like this isn't a supply/demand issue. I think actually it's possible this market got broken due to outsized, black swan moves from stocks like CRM, ZM and DOCU who didn't even have an earnings yet that MM are so pressed to selling vol they jacked up everything arbitrarily across all names, which includes Tesla and CRM but should include others, which I haven't delved into.

author: infinitelimits00
body:
I don't think there would be many links talking about this but ZeroHedge did mention the call skew effect in tech in a recent article. I know it's ZeroHedge and they are permabears, but the data seems accurate. Essentially MM are so short calls right now that calls in some names cost 4x as much as puts the same strike away from spot. So a move like CRM or ZM to the upside makes the move like 5x larger. 

https://www.zerohedge.com/markets/apples-market-cap-surpasses-entire-russell-2000-due-option-insanity

author: OptionExpiration
body:
Since you worked at SIG, let's use the poker analogy. We know that retail has been buying calls across the board. We are short gamma and short so many calls. So we don't want to sell any more options at an x volatility. So retail keeps on buying at x+y and then x+y+z, etc. We keep on making sales at these 'inflated' prices and they keep on buying them.

I presume this phenomena is happening in AAPL. Got steamrolled in CRM (what a move) and ZM (today). So we keep on offering at higher and higher levels (and retail keeps on buying) which is nuts.

Because the big tech stocks make up a huge portion on the NDX (QQQ) and SPX (SPY), we can get a little hedge on buy bidding up calls in the NDX (QQQ) and SPX (SPY). Because we are bidding up calls, we are now impacting VIX.

This is the only explanation I have for you. I think you are probably OK selling a little vol here (but I would go smaller size because of this craziness... vol can still go higher).

author: OptionExpiration
body:
My feeling is that there is genuine panic at these market making firms because of these insane moves that just do not make sense (but they still continue because of the feedback loop). I would bet that a senior trader/partner has taken over these names (TSLA AAPL CRM FB GOOG etc) to make sure that the firm doesn't get clobbered too much.

We all know to respect the markets, but at some level the 'madness' has to end. Of course, nobody knows when that will happen. Notwithstanding, the 'edge' you get selling at x+y+z volatility is more than you got at x+y which is more than what you got at x. You may be wrong at the x and x+y levels, but at the x+y+z level you made up for your losses (from x and X+y) and then some. Thus, the snowball effect of implied volatility becoming actual volatility might be true at the x and x+y level and overstated at the x+y+z level. (There has to be some edge selling options because you need a balance sheet selling options versus buying options).

So I do agree with what you are saying that the implieds will eventually be overstating what is happening with actual volatility. Unfortunately, nobody knows what level this will be. Thus, selling vol in small pieces at higher and higher levels is probably the safest way of doing this (and this is probably what the market makers are doing). You should have enough edge that you can scratch a trade if it doesn't feel right...
